record.text: The LLM itself intrinsically biases the search. Even if directly instructed to look for new data, it will be summarized against a set of weights heavily skewed towards the past, biasing any summarization, if not the queries it's making & summarizing from. It's semiotic/liminal space is too static.

Plus, this is a chance to put all of Copilot's losses & infrastructure expenditure on Github's balance sheet as "R&D overhead," so magically the Copilot side might look much healthier than it actually is, while, Github, already a "loser" a la Bing, just has bigger losses.

images.alt:
Last summer, more than a hundred people crowded into the brightly lit basement of a Lululemon store in Manhattan at the invitation of Lacework, a cybersecurity unicorn. By all appearances, the startup seemed to enjoy an enviable position, with an $8.3 billion valuation and an assortment of blue-chip investors, including Sutter Hill Ventures, Coatue Management and Tiger Global Management. But behind the scenes, Lacework CEO Jay Parikh was, in fact, desperate to rekindle the company’s growth, which had slowed dramatically. To lure event attendees into mingling with Lacework salespeople at the store, the company handed out $300 Lululemon gift cards to each of them, at a total cost of more than $30,000, said a former Lacework employee involved in organizing the event.

Like many ploys attempted by Parikh and Lacework over the last several years, the event was for naught. According to someone present at the event, the majority of the people who showed up for it didn’t end up becoming customers of the company, whose main product is software that sits in customers’ cloud servers, flagging potential abnormalities that could be signs of a hack. Similarly lavish giveaways of goodies have also failed to yield results for Lacework.

Al menos 40 personas han muerto en un ataque llevado a cabo este lunes y achacado a las Fuerzas de Apoyo Rápido (RSF) contra un campamento de desplazados situado en los alrededores de la ciudad de…

external.description: Al menos 40 personas han muerto en un ataque llevado a cabo este lunes y achacado a las Fuerzas de Apoyo Rápido (RSF) contra un campamento de desplazados situado en los alrededores de la ciudad de El Fasher, capital de la provincia sudanesa de Darfur Norte, según ha denunciado una organización de activistas. La Sala de Emergencias del campamento de Abú Shuk, que ha informado de que otras 19 personas han resultado heridas, ha señalado que las RSF irrumpieron en el lugar, abriendo fuego dentro de las casas de los residentes y las calles, según reza un comunicado publicado en su cuenta en la red social Facebook.

La memoria es uno de los factores que más importancia se le da a medida que te vas haciendo mayor. En muchas ocasiones se piensa que el deterioro del cerebro y de la capacidad para…

external.description: La memoria es uno de los factores que más importancia se le da a medida que te vas haciendo mayor. En muchas ocasiones se piensa que el deterioro del cerebro y de la capacidad para retener información empeora considerablemente con el paso de los años. Sin embargo, un estudio liderado por científicos de la Facultad de Medicina de la Universidad Northwestern, en Estados Unidos, ha confirmado que es posible llegar a los 80 años con una mente 30 años más joven.

images.alt: Better instructions, worse output
Better instructions, worse output

What part of the transition from the list to the image made it go off the rails?


ChatGPT said:
The main issue happened in the data handoff from your clean, accurate text list of presidents to the image-generation step.

When the list was converted into a visual grid, several things went wrong:

Names were mistyped or truncated

Example: “John F. Kennedy” became “Jonn F. Kennedy”.

Years in office were swapped, reversed, or illogical

Example: “Lyndon B. Johnson” was listed as 1961–1963, but should be 1963–1969.

Several other date ranges were scrambled (e.g., Reagan, Bush, Clinton).

Chronological continuity was lost

The original list followed an exact historical sequence, but the image generator treated it as raw text without validating dates or order.

Image generator doesn’t inherently “know” U.S. history

It pulls patterns from the input text and training data but doesn’t fact-check or ensure internal consistency—so if any small error creeps in, it happily repeats or compounds it.

Basically, you went from a structured, fact-checked text to a free-form AI rendering, and the second step lacked the historical grounding that kept your original list accurate.

If you want, I can show you how to keep the next image historically correct by feeding the generator strictly formatted, locked-in data rather than letting it “interpret” the list.

images.alt:
Last summer, more than a hundred people crowded into the brightly lit basement of a Lululemon store in Manhattan at the invitation of Lacework, a cybersecurity unicorn. By all appearances, the startup seemed to enjoy an enviable position, with an $8.3 billion valuation and an assortment of blue-chip investors, including Sutter Hill Ventures, Coatue Management and Tiger Global Management. But behind the scenes, Lacework CEO Jay Parikh was, in fact, desperate to rekindle the company’s growth, which had slowed dramatically. To lure event attendees into mingling with Lacework salespeople at the store, the company handed out $300 Lululemon gift cards to each of them, at a total cost of more than $30,000, said a former Lacework employee involved in organizing the event.

Like many ploys attempted by Parikh and Lacework over the last several years, the event was for naught. According to someone present at the event, the majority of the people who showed up for it didn’t end up becoming customers of the company, whose main product is software that sits in customers’ cloud servers, flagging potential abnormalities that could be signs of a hack. Similarly lavish giveaways of goodies have also failed to yield results for Lacework.
